books.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 1

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 1:1
verses.text: Book XI.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 1:2
verses.text: Of the Spirit of Vainglory.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 1:3
verses.text: Chapter I.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 1:4
verses.text: How our seventh combat is against the spirit of vainglory, and what its nature.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 1:5
verses.text: Our seventh combat is against the spirit of κενοδοξία, which we may term vain or idle glory: a spirit that takes many shapes, and is changeable and subtle, so that it can with difficulty, I will not say be guarded against, but be seen through and discovered even by the keenest eyes.

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 2

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 2:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 2:2
verses.text: How vainglory attacks a monk not only on his carnal, but also on his spiritual side.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 2:3
verses.text: For not only does this, like the rest of his faults, attack a monk on his carnal side, but on his spiritual side as well, insinuating itself by craft and guile into his mind: so that those who cannot be deceived by carnal vices are more grievously wounded through their spiritual proficiency; and it is so much the worse to fight against, as it is harder to guard against.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 2:4
verses.text: For the attack of all other vices is more open and straightforward, and in the case of each of them, when he who stirs them up is met by a determined refusal, he will go away the weaker for it, and the adversary who has been beaten will on the next occasion attack his victim with less vigour.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 2:5
verses.text: But this malady when it has attacked the mind by means of carnal pride, and has been repulsed by the shield of reply, again, like some wickedness that takes many shapes, changes its former guise and character, and under the appearance of the virtues tries to strike down and destroy its conqueror.

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 3

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 3:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 3:2
verses.text: How many forms and shapes vainglory takes.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 3:3
verses.text: For our other faults and passions may be said to be simpler and of but one form: but this takes many forms and shapes, and changes about and assails the man who stands up against it from every quarter, and assaults its conqueror on all sides.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 3:4
verses.text: For it tries to injure the soldier of Christ in his dress, in his manner, his walk, his voice, his work, his vigils, his fasts, his prayers, when he withdraws, when he reads, in his knowledge, his silence, his obedience, his humility, his patience; and like some most dangerous rock hidden by surging waves, it causes an unforeseen and miserable shipwreck to those who are sailing with a fair breeze, while they are not on the lookout for it or guarding against it.

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 4

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 4:2
verses.text: How vainglory attacks a monk on the right had and on the left.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 4:3
verses.text: And so one who wishes to go along the King's highway by means of the "arms of righteousness which are on the right hand and on the left," ought by the teaching of the Apostle to pass through "honour and dishonour, evil report and good report," and with such care to direct his virtuous course amid the swelling waves of temptation, with discretion at the helm, and the Spirit of the Lord breathing on us, since we know that if we deviate ever so little to the right hand or to the left, we shall presently be dashed against most dangerous crags.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 4:4
verses.text: And so we are warned by Solomon, the wisest of men: "Turn not aside to the right hand or to the left;" i-e:, do not flatter yourself on your virtues and be puffed up by your spiritual achievements on the right hand; nor, swerving to the path of vices on the left hand, seek from them for yourself (to use the words of the Apostle) "glory in your shame".

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 4:5
verses.text: For where the devil cannot create vainglory in a man by means of his well-fitting and neat dress, he tries to introduce it by means of a dirty, cheap, and uncared-for style.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 4:6
verses.text: If he cannot drag a man down by honour, he overthrows him by humility.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 4:7
verses.text: If he cannot make him puffed up by the grace of knowledge and eloquence, he pulls him down by the weight of silence.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 4:8
verses.text: If a man fasts openly, he is attacked by the pride of vanity.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 4:9
verses.text: If he conceals it for the sake of despising the glory of it, he is assailed by the same sin of pride.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 4:10
verses.text: In order that he may not be defiled by the stains of vainglory he avoids making long prayers in the sight of the brethren; and yet because he offers them secretly and has no one who is conscious of it, he does not escape the pride of vanity.

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 5

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 5:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 5:2
verses.text: A comparison which shows the nature of vainglory.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 5:3
verses.text: Our elders admirably describe the nature of this malady as like that of an onion, and of those bulbs which when stripped of one covering you find to be sheathed in another; and as often as you strip them, you find them still protected.

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 6

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 6:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 6:2
verses.text: That vainglory is not altogether got rid of by the advantages of solitude.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 6:3
verses.text: In solitude also it does not cease from pursuing him who has for the sake of glory fled from intercourse with all men.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 6:4
verses.text: And the more thoroughly a man has shunned the whole world, so much the more keenly does it pursue him.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 6:5
verses.text: It tries to lift up with pride one man because of his great endurance of work and labour, another because of his extreme readiness to obey, another because he outstrips other men in humility.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 6:6
verses.text: One man is tempted through the extent of his knowledge, another through the extent of his reading, another through the length of his vigils.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 6:7
verses.text: Nor does this malady endeavour to wound a man except through his virtues; introducing hindrances which lead to death by means of those very things through which the supplies of life are sought.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 6:8
verses.text: For when men are anxious to walk in the path of holiness and perfection, the enemies do not lay their snares to deceive them anywhere except in the way along which they walk, in accordance with that saying of the blessed David: "In the way wherein I walked have they laid a snare for me;" that in this very way of virtue along which we are walking, when pressing on to "the prize of our high calling," we may be elated by our successes, and so sink down, and fall with the feet of our soul entangled and caught in the snares of vainglory.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 6:9
verses.text: And so it results that those of us who could not be vanquished in the conflict with the foe are overcome by the very greatness of our triumph, or else (which is another kind of deception) that, overstraining the limits of that self-restraint which is possible to us, we fail of perseverance in our course on account of bodily weakness.

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 7

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 7:1
verses.text: Chapter VII.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 7:2
verses.text: How vainglory, when it has been overcome, rises again keener than ever for the fight.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 7:3
verses.text: All vices when overcome grow feeble, and when beaten are day by day rendered weaker, and both in regard to place and time grow less and subside, or at any rate, as they are unlike the opposite virtues, are more easily shunned and avoided: but this one when it is beaten rises again keener than ever for the struggle; and when we think that it is destroyed, it revives again, the stronger for its  death.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 7:4
verses.text: The other kinds of vices usually only attack those whom they have overcome in the conflict; but this one pursues its victors only the more keenly; and the more thoroughly it has been resisted, so much the more vigorously does it attack the man who is elated by his victory over it.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 7:5
verses.text: And herein lies the crafty cunning of our adversary, namely, in the fact that, where he cannot overcome the soldier of Christ by the weapons of the foe, he lays him low by his own spear.

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 8

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 8:1
verses.text: Chapter VIII.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 8:2
verses.text: How vainglory is not allayed either in the desert or through advancing years.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 8:3
verses.text: Other vices, as we said, are sometimes allayed by the advantages of position, and when the matter of the sin and the occasion and opportunity for it are removed, grow slack, and are diminished: but this one penetrates the deserts with the man who is flying from it, nor can it be shut out from any place, nor when outward material for it is removed does it fail.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 8:4
verses.text: For it is simply encouraged by the achievements of the virtues of the man whom it attacks.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 8:5
verses.text: For all other vices, as we said above, are sometimes diminished by the lapse of time, and disappear: to this one length of life, unless it is supported by skilful diligence and prudent discretion, is no hindrance, but actually supplies it with new fuel for vanity.

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 9

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 9:1
verses.text: Chapter IX.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 9:2
verses.text: That vainglory is the more dangerous through being mixed up with virtues.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 9:3
verses.text: Lastly, other passions which are entirely different from the virtues which are their opposites, and which attack us openly and as it were in broad daylight, are more easily overcome and guarded against: but this being interwoven with our virtues and entangled in the battle, fighting as it were under cover of the darkness of night, deceives the more dangerously those who are off their guard and not on the lookout.

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 10

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 10:1
verses.text: Chapter X.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 10:2
verses.text: An instance showing how King Hezekiah was overthrown by the dart of vainglory.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 10:3
verses.text: For so we read that Hezekiah, King of Judah, a man of most perfect righteousness in all things, and one approved by the witness of Holy Scripture, after unnumbered commendations for his virtues, was overthrown by a single dart of vainglory.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 10:4
verses.text: And he who by a single prayer of his was able to procure the death of a hundred and eighty-five thousand of the army of the Assyrians, whom the angel destroyed in one night, is overcome by boasting and vanity.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 10:5
verses.text: Of whom—to pass over the long list of his virtues, which it would take a long time to unfold—I will say but this one thing.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 10:6
verses.text: He was a man who, after the close of his life had been decreed and the day of his death determined by the Lord's sentence, prevailed by a single prayer to extend the limits set to his life by fifteen years, the sun returning by ten steps, on which it had already shone in its course towards its setting, and by its return dispersing those lines which the shadow that followed its course had already marked, and by this giving two days in one to the whole world, by a stupendous miracle contrary to the fixed laws of nature.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 10:7
verses.text: Yet after signs so great and so incredible, after such immense proofs of his goodness, hear the Scripture tell how he was destroyed by his very successes.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 10:8
verses.text: "In those days," we are told, "Hezekiah was sick unto death: and he prayed to the Lord, and He heard him and gave him a sign," that, namely of which we read in the fourth book of the kingdoms, which was given by Isaiah the prophet through the going back of the sun.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 10:9
verses.text: "But," it says, "he did not render again according to the benefits which he had received, for his heart was lifted up; and wrath was kindled against him and against Judah and Jerusalem: and he humbled himself afterwards because his heart had been lifted up, both he and the inhabitants of Jerusalem, and therefore the wrath of the Lord came not upon them in the days of Hezekiah".

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 10:10
verses.text: How dangerous, how terrible is the malady of vanity! So much goodness, so many virtues, faith and devotion, great enough to prevail to change nature itself and the laws of the whole world, perish by a single act of pride! So that all his good deeds would have been forgotten as if they had never been, and he would at once have been subject to the wrath of the Lord unless he had appeased Him by recovering his humility: so that he who, at the suggestion of pride, had fallen from so great a height of excellence, could only mount again to the height he had lost by the same steps of humility.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 10:11
verses.text: Do you want to see another instance of a similar downfall?.

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 11

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 11:1
verses.text: Chapter XI.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 11:2
verses.text: The instance of King Uzziah who was overcome by the taint of the same malady.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 11:3
verses.text: Of Uzziah, the ancestor of this king of whom we have been speaking, himself also praised in all things by the witness of the  Scripture, after great commendation for his virtue, after countless triumphs which he achieved by the merit of his devotion and faith, learn how he was cast down by the pride of vainglory.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 11:4
verses.text: "And," we are told, "the name of Uzziah went forth, for the Lord helped him and had strengthened him.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 11:5
verses.text: But when he was made strong, his heart was lifted up to his destruction, and he neglected the Lord his God".

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 11:6
verses.text: You behold another instance of a most terrible downfall, and see how two men so upright and excellent were undone by their very triumphs and victories.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 11:7
verses.text: Whence you see how dangerous the successes of prosperity generally are, so that those who could not be injured by adversity are ruined, unless they are careful, by prosperity; and those who in the conflict of battle have escaped the danger of death fall before their own trophies and triumphs.

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 12

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 12:2
verses.text: Several testimonies against vainglory.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 12:3
verses.text: And so the Apostle warns us: "Be not desirous of vainglory".

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 12:4
verses.text: And the Lord, rebuking the Pharisees, says, "How can ye believe, who receive glory from one another, and seek not the glory which comes from God alone?" Of these too the blessed David speaks with a threat: "For God hath scattered the bones of them that please men".

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 13

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 13:2
verses.text: Of the ways in which vainglory attacks a monk.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 13:3
verses.text: In the case also of beginners and of those who have as yet made but little progress either in powers of mind or in knowledge it usually puffs up their minds, either because of the quality of their voice because they can sing well, or because their bodies are emaciated, or because they are of a good figure, or because they have rich and noble kinsfolk, or because they have despised a military life and honours.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 13:4
verses.text: Sometimes too it persuades a man that if he had remained in the world he would easily have obtained honours and riches, which perhaps could not possibly have been secured, and inflates him with a vain hope of uncertain things; and in the case of those things which he never possessed, puffs him up with pride and vanity, as if he were one who had despised them.

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 14

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIV.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 14:2
verses.text: How it suggests that a man may seek to take holy orders.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 14:3
verses.text: But sometimes it creates a wish to take holy orders, and a desire for the priesthood or diaconate.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 14:4
verses.text: And it represents that if a man has even against his will received this office, he will fulfil it with such sanctity and strictness that he will be able to set an example of saintliness even to other priests; and that he will win over many people, not only by his manner of life, but also by his teaching and preaching.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 14:5
verses.text: It makes a man, even when alone and sitting in his cell, to go round in mind and imagination to the dwellings and monasteries of others, and to make many conversions under the inducements of imaginary exultation.

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 15

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 15:1
verses.text: Chapter XV.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 15:2
verses.text: How vainglory intoxicates the mind.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 15:3
verses.text: And so the miserable soul is affected by such vanity—as if it were deluded by a profound slumber—that it is often led away by the pleasure of such thoughts, and filled with such imaginations, so that it cannot even look at things present, or the brethren, while it enjoys dwelling upon these things, of which with its wandering thoughts it has waking dreams, as if they were true.

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 16

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 16:1
verses.text: Chapter XVI.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 16:2
verses.text: Of him whom the superior came upon and found in his cell, deluded by idle vainglory.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 16:3
verses.text: I remember an elder, when I was staying in the desert of Scete, who went to the cell of a certain brother to pay him a visit, and when he had reached the door heard him muttering inside, and stood still for a little while, wanting to know what it was that he was reading from the Bible or repeating by heart (as is customary) while he was at work.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 16:4
verses.text: And when this most excellent eavesdropper diligently applied his ear and listened with some curiosity, he found that the man was induced by an attack of this spirit to fancy that he was delivering a stirring sermon to the people.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 16:5
verses.text: And when the elder, as he stood still, heard him finish his discourse and return again to his office, and give out the dismissal of the catechumens, as the deacon does, then at last he  knocked at the door, and the man came out, and met the elder with the customary reverence, and brought him in and (for his knowledge of what had been his thoughts made him uneasy) asked him when he had arrived, for fear lest he might have taken some harm from standing too long at the door: and the old man joking pleasantly replied, "I only got here while you were giving out the dismissal of the catechumens".

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 17

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 17:1
verses.text: Chapter XVII.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 17:2
verses.text: How faults cannot be cured unless their roots and causes have been discovered.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 17:3
verses.text: I thought it well to insert these things in this little work of mine, that we might learn, not only by reason, but also by examples, about the force of temptations and the order of the sins which hurt an unfortunate soul, and so might be more careful in avoiding the snares and manifold deceits of the enemy.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 17:4
verses.text: For these things are indiscriminately brought forward by the Egyptian fathers, that by telling them, as those who are still enduring them, they may disclose and lay bare the combats with all the vices, which they actually do suffer, and those which the younger ones are sure to suffer; so that, when they explain the illusions arising from all the passions, those who are but beginners and fervent in spirit may know the secret of their struggles, and seeing them as in a glass, may learn both the causes of the sins by which they are troubled, and the remedies for them, and instructed beforehand concerning the approach of future struggles, may be taught how they ought to guard against them, or to meet them and to fight with them.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 17:5
verses.text: As clever physicians are accustomed not only to heal already existing diseases, but also by a wise skill to seek to obviate future ones, and to prevent them by their prescriptions and healing draughts, so these true physicians of the soul, by means of spiritual conferences, like some celestial antidote, destroy beforehand those maladies of the soul which would arise, and do not allow them to gain a footing in the minds of the juniors, as they unfold to them the causes of the passions which threaten them, and the remedies which will heal them.

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 18

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 18:2
verses.text: How a monk ought to avoid women and bishops.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 18:3
verses.text: Wherefore this is an old maxim of the Fathers that is still current,—though I cannot produce it without shame on my own part, since I could not avoid my own sister, nor escape the hands of the bishop,—viz.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 18:4
verses.text: , that a monk ought by all means to fly from women and bishops.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 18:5
verses.text: For neither of them will allow him who has once been joined in close intercourse any longer to care for the quiet of his cell, or to continue with pure eyes in divine contemplation through his insight into holy things.

chapters.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 19

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 19:2
verses.text: Remedies by which we can overcome vainglory.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 19:3
verses.text: And so the athlete of Christ who desires to strive lawfully in this true and spiritual combat, should strive by all means to overcome this changeable monster of many shapes, which, as it attacks us on every side like some manifold wickedness, we can escape by such a remedy as this; viz.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 19:4
verses.text: , thinking on that saying of David: "The Lord hath scattered the bones of those who please men".

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 19:5
verses.text: To begin with we should not allow ourselves to do anything at the suggestion of vanity, and for the sake of obtaining vainglory.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 19:6
verses.text: Next, when we have begun a thing well, we should endeavour to maintain it with just the same care, for fear lest afterwards the malady of vainglory should creep in and make void all the fruits of our labours.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 19:7
verses.text: And anything which is of very little use or value in the common life of the brethren, we should avoid as leading to boasting; and whatever would render us remarkable amongst the others, and for which credit would be gained among men, as if we were the only people who could do it, this should be shunned by us.

verses.name: John Cassian: The Twelve Books XI 19:8
verses.text: For by these signs the deadly taint of vainglory will be shown to cling to us: which we shall most easily escape if we consider that we shall not merely lose the fruits of those labours of ours which we have performed at the suggestion of vainglory, but that we shall also be guilty of a great sin, and as impious persons undergo eternal punishments, inasmuch as we have wronged God by doing for the favour of men what we ought to have done for His sake, and are convicted by Him who knows all secrets of having preferred men to God, and the praise of the world to the praise of the Lord.
